title: Kenneth Mason, Quaker Oats President in 1970s, Defended Cap’n Crunch
text:
As president of Quaker Oats Co. in the 1970s, Kenneth Mason’s job included defending the company from consumer-protection groups arguing that its sugary Cap’n Crunch cereal rotted children’s teeth and was generally bad for their health.

He pointed to what he saw as a bigger threat to children. Saturday-morning cartoons on television, he said, were rotting their minds. Mr. Mason proposed that the commercial-TV networks team up to produce higher-quality shows, akin to “Sesame Street.” For its part, Quaker Oats would support...
description: Kenneth Mason, president of Quaker Oats in the late 1970s, defended the company’s Cap’n Crunch cereal as good for kids—but deplored the mindless cartoons they were watching on TV. Mr. Mason retired early, at 57, to contemplate and write. He died Sept. 4 at age 97.
